intro: Carex hispida var. anacantha, commonly known as the rough sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to North America. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its triangular stems and grass-like leaves. The plant typically grows in moist to wet habitats such as marshes, swamps, and along stream banks. Its flowering spikes, which appear in late spring to early summer, consist of small, greenish-brown flowers arranged in dense clusters. Carex hispida var. anacantha plays an important ecological role by providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
